subject: Katana/nagamaki and blade inscriptiion - Harry..where are you?
msgSnippet: Barry, I appreciate the comments. My photography was horrible on this one..I had 5 minutes in bad light. The boshi is intact and healthy. No hagire anywhere.

Barry,
I appreciate the comments. My photography was horrible on this one..=
I
had 5 minutes in bad light. The boshi is intact and healthy. No hagire
an=
ywhere. The polish is a nasty semi-amateur job that makes it look
worse the=
n it is. The sword is actually very nice. In person, the
hamon is clear and=
 has some activity. Lines are sharp and clean.
Yes..I agree it looks o-suri=
ge. Some opinions have been that it is a
nagamaki naoshi shortened and resh=
aped in shinshinto or shinto times,
and the inscriptions were done at that =
time. 
They seem to be in the Chinese style of writing, and boast about the=

sharpness of the sword. Would be very interested in a translation from
Har=
ry, as I am told he is familiar with this type of language.
This one you ha=
ve to hold in hand to appreciate. Nothing fantastic,
but has a nice sugata =
and nice lines. Fairly thick. I will try next
time to do better shots of th=
e whole blade, and give dimensions.
Thanks for the comments and views. Much=
 appreciated.

Brian

essions is that the sword could be (could be!!) Sue Koto.

what I can see the sword is still "no chop"and the nakago suggests

rd is

ord is a poor

ng about
the Sword as

battlefield.  Given

only...
